profileText: A Representative from Minnesota; born in Anoka County, Minn., March 12, 1880; attended the public schools; was graduated from the University of Minnesota at Minneapolis in 1903; attended the law department of the University of Minnesota in 1904, 1905, 1915, and 1916; engaged in the publishing and printing business at Anoka, Minn., 1904-1914; municipal judge of Anoka, Minn., 1911-1916; deputy State auditor and land commissioner of Minnesota 1916-1920; was graduated from the St. Paul (Minn.) College of Law in 1919; was admitted to the bar the same year but did not practice; State auditor and land commissioner of Minnesota 1921-1931; unsuccessful Republican candidate for Governor of Minnesota in 1930; elected as a Republican to the Seventy-third Congress (March 4, 1933-January 3, 1935); unsuccessful candidate for renomination in 1934; practiced law, specializing in legal research, 1935-1943; member of the Minnesota Railroad and Warehouse Commission 1944-1948; died in Anoka, Minn., on September 18, 1948; interment in Forest Hill Cemetery.

creativeWork.freeFormCitationText: Chase, Ray Park. Are they communists or catspaws? [Anoka, Minn.: N.p., 1938].
------. The path of your tax dollar. Minneapolis, Minn.: Taxpayers Association, [1924].

researchRecord.name: ca. 1897-1944, 18.25 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: The papers of Ray Park Chase contain correspondence, notes, reports, news releases, clippings, and printed materials on matters of interest to Chase, who served as Minnesota state auditor and land commissioner (1921-1931), U.S. congressman (1933-1934), and Republican political researcher (1930s). They focus on tax rates and procedures; economics; Minnesota government administration and finances; conservation of water and timber resources; regulation of hydroelectric power developments; accusations of graft and misgovernment against the Minnesota Farmer-Labor party and the national Democratic party; New Deal agricultural, relief, and regulatory programs during the Depression of the 1930s, especially the Works Projects Administration; Republican party activities; Chase's campaigns for various state and national political offices; communist, socialist, and pacifist activities in the U.S. and at the University of Minnesota; and alleged communist influences in the Farmer-Labor party. An inventory is available in the repository.
